bibl.title: Letter from E.R. Dean to Howard A. Kelly, April 2, 1907

div1.p: Dean writes about the financial and physical condition of Kissinger (a yellow fever experiment patient) and discusses a pension bill for him in Congress.

div1.head: Letter from E.R. Dean to Howard A. Kelly, April 2, 1907
div1.opener:
W.R.
SoBend Ind.
April-2-07.
Dear Dr. Kelley:-
div1.p:
In reply to your
letter of inquiry concerning
John R. Kissinger.

I am quite sure from what
he tells me, and all I am able
to find in his case, that there
is no syphilis. He is quite
positive that he has not had any
venerial disease. He is rather
intelligent, I consider above the
average man, and would know
and inform me, if he had had;
as I explained to him, it was very
important to be frank on this subject.

I had this man at my office
and invited in a number of
physicians, they diagnosed it
myeliti's but could not assign a cause.
He is very temperate does not drink
or chew, occasionally smokes. They
are a good family that is intelligent,
saving, appreciative people, I think
they would save their money if they
were helped. He and his wife want
to make a living, he, I think was
a machinist, she a milliner, before
his affliction last autumn, from
that time to the present she felt that she
could not leave home as he needed
her help so has stayed with him
and worked.

They are in poor circumstances
now, I tried very hard to help toward
a special pension bill so Congressman
a.L. Brick got an act through
allowing $50.00 per. month. But it
was cut down in the senate so that
it now stands at $12.00 and I
do not know when he will get it.

If any more information is
desired please write as I am
also very much interested in
this unfortunate hero.
div1.closer:
I am
fraternally E. R. Dean.
